segments.text: There have been some improvements.
It's interesting.
Sam Snead said the most improvement that you have is in the golf ball.
He would take a wood wood and a new ball, and he'd take a metal wood and a new ball, and he'd hit them pretty much the same distance.
and demonstrate it isn't the club as much as it is the ball.
But there have been some definite improvements on it.
I think your clubs come out more the same.
There is much more of a demand and a stress on having very high quality as far as not being deviating a lot.
And that's helped a lot in consistency.
But the main thing actually is just

The amount of them, the amount of schools for these young people to go to, golf schools, I mean, they're off in the summertime or holidays, and the instruction at these schools, and the instruction level with PGA professionals has just really improved.
You can become a better player with the help of these people who really learn it.
And I think that's where you've seen really the biggest improvement.
The equipment to some degree, but the instruction, the opportunity to compete, that makes the best player.
If you have to compete one against one, you're going to improve a lot.

I really, when I think about this, and this is going to go counter where a lot of people think, but the first ones that I had in the middle 70s, some of these kids with cancer were just really, really tough.
In the 70s, a lot of kids with cancer, they were tough to deal with.
And they lied to you a lot.
They were hard to deal with.
And as I went along, they got a little better in the 80s.
And I'm not saying always.
I don't want to color Danny and some of these kids up.
Some of them are just real good.
He has about since 1990.
I don't know what it is, but the kids have changed, and they're better.
And I think they've been getting better.
I always tell people who come up to me and say, boy, Coach, you've got great kids.
It's because they've got great parents.
And I think parents are doing a better job with their kids.
I think the kids now are better than what they were.
Well, it's definitely improved.
I remember we used to go to Guadalajara.
In fact, we won it.
There was a golf course.
It was really a big time thing in 1980.
All the major schools were there.
I remember we were paired against Oklahoma State, Bob Clay, and these people would beat us.
He was a great player.
We beat them.
They shot 878.
And individually, I believe it was 218 won the tournament.
That was 1980.
In 1986, we went there.
840, we shot 844 going forward.
201 won individually.
And you say, well, it had to have been, you know, different.
Now, we play a Guadalajara-type club.
The weather is always the same.
Now, Rafael Arcon, he changed the team placement somewhat, but they still kept it much.
Some of those things might have been at the end, but the golf course is still the same.
The conditions are still the same.
Largely, the player had improved that much in that period of time.
And you can see it now.
I mean, the scores, when I played Dallas Athletics,
Thank you.
Is there any other team that golf or any other sports group that golfers know?
And you know he did it.
What was the punishment?
Did you go over in those six or five sessions, did you do that?
